raw_text:
Lions blow to World Cup winners
 
 British and Irish Lions coach Clive Woodward says he is unlikely to select any players not involved in next year's RBS Six Nations Championship.
 
 World Cup winners Lawrence Dallaglio, Neil Back and Martin Johnson had all been thought to be in the frame for next summer's tour to New Zealand. "I don't think you can ever say never," said Woodward. "But I would have to have a compulsive reason to pick any player who is not available to international rugby." Dallaglio, Back and Johnson have all retired from international rugby over the last 12 months but continue to star for their club sides. But Woodward added: "The key thing that I want to stress is that I intend to use the Six Nations and the players who are available to international rugby as the key benchmark. "My job, along with all the other senior representatives, is to make sure that we pick the strongest possible team. "If you are not playing international rugby then it's still a step up to Test rugby. It's definitely a disadvantage.
 
 "I think it's absolutely critical and with the history of the Lions we have got to take players playing for the four countries." Woodward also revealed that the race for the captaincy was still wide open. "It is an open book," he said. "There are some outstanding candidates from all four countries." And following the All Blacks' impressive displays in Europe in recent weeks, including a 45-6 humiliation of France, Woodward believes the three-test series in New Zealand will provide the ultimate rugby challenge. "Their performance in particular against France was simply awesome," said the Lions coach. "Certain things have been suggested about the potency of their front five, but they're a very powerful unit." With his customary thoroughness, Woodward revealed he had taken soundings from Australia coach Eddie Jones and Jake White of South Africa following their tour matches in Britain and Ireland.
 
 As a result, Woodward stressed his Lions group might not be dominated by players from England and Ireland and held out hope for the struggling Scots. "Scotland's recent results have not been that impressive but there have been some excellent individual performances. "Eddie in particular told me how tough they had made it for Australia and I will take on board their opinions." And Scotland forward Simon Taylor looks certain to get the call, provided he recovers from knee and tendon problems. "I took lessons from 2001 in that they did make a mistake in taking Lawrence Dallaglio when he wasn't fit and went on the trip. "Every player has to be looked at on their own merits and Simon Taylor is an outstanding player and I have no doubts that if he gets back to full fitness he will be on the trip. "I am told he should be back playing by March and he has plenty of time to prove his fitness for the Lions - and there are other players like Richard Hill in the same boat."
llama3.2:1b: Clive Woodward, British and Irish Lions coach, says World Cup winners Lawrence Dallaglio, Neil Back, and Martin Johnson may not be selected due to their retirement from international rugby. Woodward wants to use the Six Nations Championship as a benchmark for selection, as players playing in Test rugby are considered stronger. The race for the captaincy is still open with many candidates from all four countries competing.
llama3.2:3b: British and Irish Lions coach Clive Woodward says no player not involved in next year's Six Nations will be selected, but emphasizes using international rugby as a key benchmark. He considers World Cup winners Lawrence Dallaglio, Neil Back, and Martin Johnson for the tour to New Zealand despite their recent club performances. Woodward believes the series against New Zealand will provide an ultimate challenge after the All Blacks' impressive displays in Europe.
gemma2:2b: Clive Woodward will prioritize players involved in the 2015 Six Nations Championship for the upcoming Lions tour to New Zealand. He believes the strongest team will be chosen based on international rugby availability.  The race for the captaincy is wide open, with multiple candidates from all four participating countries. The All Blacks' recent performances and the challenge posed by their front five are considered key aspects in preparation for the three-test series. Woodward has consulted with Eddie Jones and Jake White regarding upcoming tours of Australia and South Africa respectively. Scotland is expected to receive a stronger representation on the team, based on individual player performance as well as advice from coaches like Eddie Jones and Jake White.  Players such as Simon Taylor are in contention for inclusion, pending recovery from injury.
qwen2.5:0.5b: British and Irish Lions coach Clive Woodward says he would have to select any player not available to international rugby. He plans to use the Six Nations and the players who are available to international rugby as the key benchmark. Scotland's performance in Europe last week against France is described positively by Woodward, while England and Ireland suffer from problems with Dallaglio and Johnson. Scotland's individual performances are mentioned.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Lions coach Clive Woodward indicates no Lions selection beyond those participating in next year's RBS Six Nations Championship. Despite Lawrence Dallaglio, Neil Back, and Martin Johnson retiring from international rugby recently, he intends to rely solely on club performances for the team composition. The captaincy remains open; England, Ireland, Australia, and South Africa coaches were also consulted. Woodward emphasizes using the Six Nations as a benchmark rather than solely focusing on players with national caps. He highlights New Zealand's All Blacks' impressive European tours and particularly their superior front five performance against France as key challenges for the Lions in upcoming matches there. Scotland, despite recent poor results, is expected to send a strong team due to promising individual performances and an open position for Simon Taylor.
qwen2.5:3b: British and Irish Lions coach Clive Woodward says he is unlikely to select any players not involved in next year's RBS Six Nations Championship. He stated that only those available for international rugby will be considered, excluding World Cup winners Lawrence Dallaglio, Neil Back, and Martin Johnson who have retired but still play club rugby. Woodward emphasized the importance of the Lions team being the strongest possible, with non-international players at a disadvantage. The race for the captaincy is open to candidates from all four countries. He also praised New Zealand's All Blacks' recent performances and hopes for Scotland's participation in the tour based on their recent individual performances, despite poor overall results.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>

First, the text talks about the Lions choosing not to include any players from England or Ireland unless they've been in previous Six Nations games. That makes sense because they want to maintain a strong international rugby team by using their existing top players as benchmarks.

Then, there's mention of the world cup winners Lawrence Dallaglio, Neil Back, and Martin Johnson. They all were thought to be part of the Six Nations bracket but now have retired from international rugby. However, they still play for their clubs. Woodward emphasizes that it's a step up to Test rugby but also stresses sticking with the players who are already in international rugby.

He also mentions that his goal is to select the strongest possible team using available players as the benchmark, which includes all four countries. The race for captaincy isn't open yet; some candidates from each country are still competing.

Woodward talks about the All Blacks' impressive European results, including a strong performance against France, suggesting they have a very powerful front five. He notes that while their England team hasn't been great, they're doing better than before. The New Zealand Three Test series could be the ultimate challenge for them.

The Lions are hopeful that the upcoming matches will push them to play from Scotland and Ireland. Woodward mentioned Eddie Jones and Jake White who went on tours in Britain and Ireland. He talked about their mistakes but noted that players must be evaluated individually, especially Simon Taylor who looked fit and is expected to return soon.

I need to condense this into a concise summary without explanations. Let me outline the key points:

1. Woodward doesn't include England or Ireland players unless they've been in previous Six Nations.
2. The three world cup winners are still playing for their clubs but not in international rugby.
3. Woodward wants to use available players as the benchmark, including all four countries.
4. There's an open race for captaincy among candidates from various countries.
5. The All Blacks have done well against France, suggesting a strong front five.
6. New Zealand Three Test series is expected to be the main challenge.
7. The upcoming matches are hopeful about playing from Scotland and Ireland.
8. Woodward talked to Eddie Jones and Jake White who were on their tours.
9. Players should be evaluated individually, especially Simon Taylor.

I need to make sure each of these points is covered clearly in a summary without adding anything extra. Also, the output should only have plain text with no explanations or formatting.
</think>

The British Lions coach Clive Woodward has emphasized that he won't select any players from England or Ireland unless they've been in previous Six Nations games. The world cup winners, Lawrence Dallaglio, Neil Back, and Martin Johnson are still playing for their clubs but not in international rugby. Woodward aims to use available players as the benchmark, including all four countries. There is an open race for captaincy among candidates from various countries. The All Blacks have excelled against France, suggesting a powerful front five. The upcoming New Zealand Three Test series will be the ultimate challenge. The Lions are hopeful about playing from Scotland and Ireland. Woodward discussed Eddie Jones and Jake White from South Africa on his tour. Players should be evaluated individually; Simon Taylor, who is fit and expected to return soon, has a promising future in this match.
tinyllama:1.1b: A British and Irish Lion coach has said that while World Cup winners Lawrence Dallaglio, Neil Back and Martin Johnson have all been considered for next year's tour to New Zealand, he is unlikely to pick any players not involved in their club sides. Coach Clieve Woodward stated that the key benchmark for selecting players for international rugby would be based on which country they are available for Test rugby. The coach also emphasized that the upcoming three-test series against All Blacks would provide the ultimate rugby challenge, with Australian coach Eddie Jones and South African coach Jakwe White expressing interest in Lion players. Scottish forward Simon Taylor is likely to be included in the team, based on previous experiences from 2001 when they took a wrong call regarding Dallaglio's fitness for the tour. Other players like Richard Hill may also be considered, according to Woodward.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The British and Irish Lions team is set to travel to New Zealand next year, with coach Clive Woodward indicating that they will not be dominated by players from England and Ireland. 

Woodward emphasized the importance of maintaining a strong bench in international rugby, asserting that his group would make "useful decisions" based on available options. The coach also clarified that his team might not be dominated by players from England and Ireland, but might rely more heavily on talent from Scotland.

Scotland forward Simon Taylor has been struggling for the Scots, but Woodward is hopeful that he will bounce back and make the trip to New Zealand. Meanwhile, Australia coach Eddie Jones and South Africa coach Jake White have sounded out their teams following tough matches in Britain and Ireland.
phi:2.7b: The text discusses British and Irish Lions coach Clive Woodward's plans to select a team for next year's tour to New Zealand. He emphasizes using players from the upcoming RBS Six Nations Championship, which includes Lawrence Dallaglio, Neil Back, and Martin Johnson, who have all retired but continue to play club rugby. Woodward also mentions that he is open to selecting players playing for the four countries and hopes Scotland will be represented in the team. Eddie Jones and Jake White's opinions are considered, but he believes the Lions' front five would be strong with their performance against France. While Dallaglio wasn't fit during the 2001 tour, he thinks Simon Taylor has a good chance of making it to the trip if he recovers from his injuries.
orca-mini:3b: The text summarizes that Clive Woodward, the British and Irish Lions coach, does not want to pick any players who are not available for international rugby during the Six Nations Championship. He also revealed that the race for the Lions captaincy is open and that he took advice from Eddie Jones and Jake White following their tours in Britain and Ireland. Simon Taylor, a Scotland forward, looks certain to join the Lions tour as long as he recovers from injuries.
hermes3:3b: Lions coach Woodward unlikely to pick non-RBS Six Nations players, preferring ones actively involved in international rugby.

Woodward also mentioned that Scotland's Simon Taylor, who has recovered from knee and tendon problems, could be selected for the Lions tour to New Zealand.
